==Events== *[[Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina]] loses his wife in an outbreak of plague.
==Bands formed== *The ''[[Concerto delle donne]]'' is founded by [[Alfonso II, Duke of Ferrara]].
==Popular music== *First recorded appearance of the English ballad ''[[Greensleeves]]''.<ref>{{cite book|first=Frank|last=Kidson|title=English Folk-Song and Dance|publisher=Read Books|year=2008|page=26|isbn=1-4437-7289-5}}</ref>

==Deaths== *[[January 18]] – [[Antonio Scandello]], Italian composer (b. 1517) *[[April 1]] – [[Alonso Mudarra]], Spanish composer and vihuelist (b. c.1510) *[[September 15]] – [[Geert van Turnhout]], Flemish composer (b. c.1530) *[[November 30]] – [[Richard Farrant]], English composer of church music, choirmaster, playwright and theatrical producer (b. c.1530)

{{Other uses|Aerial perspective (disambiguation)}} [[File:SerraEstrela-MAR2007-5.jpg|thumb|right|250px|In this picture, the aerial perspective effect is emphasized by a series of mountains in different planes photographed in a near [[contre-jour]] situation]] [[File:Mount Feathertop, Australia - May 2005.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Aerial perspective as viewed towards a sunset, with the colour shifting toward red as a result of scattering.]] [[File:Dai Jin-Landscape in the Style of Yan Wengui.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Dai Jin]], "Landscape in the Style of Yan Wengui", Early [[Ming Dynasty]] (1368-1644); a Chinese landscape painting using "atmospheric perspective" to show recession in space.]] [[File:Frans Koppelaar - Landscape near Bologna.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Frans Koppelaar]], ''Landscape near Bologna'', 2001; a painting depicting aerial perspective: distant objects are lighter, of lower contrast, and bluer than nearer objects.]]
'''Aerial perspective''' or '''atmospheric perspective''' refers to the effect the atmosphere has on the appearance of an object as it is viewed from a distance. As the distance between an object and a viewer increases, the [[contrast (vision)|contrast]] between the object and its background decreases, and the contrast of any markings or details within the object also decreases. The colours of the object also become less [[saturation (color theory)|saturated]] and shift towards the background colour, which is usually blue, but under some conditions may be some other colour (for example, at sunrise or sunset distant colours may shift towards red).
==History==
Aerial perspective was used in paintings from the Netherlands in the 15th century, and explanations of its effects were with varying degrees of accuracy written by [[polymath]]s such as [[Leon Battista Alberti]] and [[Leonardo da Vinci]]. The latter used aerial perspective in many of his paintings such as the [[Mona Lisa]] and [[The Last Supper (Leonardo)|The Last Supper]]. Atmospheric perspective was used in Pompeian Second Style paintings, one of the [[Pompeian Styles]], dating as early as 30 BCE. A notable example is the Gardenscape from the Villa of Livia in Primaporta, Italy.
==Optics==
The major component affecting the appearance of objects during [[daylight]] is [[scattering]] of light, called [[Diffuse sky radiation|skylight]], into the [[Line-of-sight propagation|line of sight]] of the viewer. Scattering occurs from molecules of the air and also from larger particles in the atmosphere such as water vapour and smoke (see [[haze]]). Scattering adds the sky light as a [[veiling luminance]] onto the light from the object, reducing its contrast with the background sky light. Skylight usually contains more light of short [[wavelength]] than other wavelengths (this is why the sky usually appears blue), which is why distant objects appear bluish (see [[Rayleigh scattering]] for detailed explanation). A minor component is scattering of light out of the line of sight of the viewer. Under daylight, this either augments the contrast loss (e.g., for white objects) or opposes it (for dark objects). At night there is effectively no skylight (unless the [[moon]] is very bright), so scattering out of the line of sight becomes the major component affecting the appearance of [[self-luminous]] objects. Such objects have their contrasts reduced with the dark background, and their colours are shifted towards red.
==Why reducing contrast reduces clarity==
The ability of a person with normal [[visual acuity]] to see fine details is determined by his or her [[contrast sensitivity]].<ref>Kelly, D. H. (1977). Visual contrast sensitivity. Optica Acta, 24, 107-129.</ref> Contrast sensitivity is the [[Multiplicative inverse|reciprocal]] of the smallest contrast for which a person can [[Contrast (vision)|see]] a sine-wave [[grating]]. A person's [[contrast sensitivity function]] is contrast sensitivity as a function of [[spatial frequency]]. Normally, peak contrast sensitivity is at about 4 cycles per degree of [[visual angle]]. At higher spatial frequencies, comprising finer and finer lines, contrast sensitivity decreases, until at about 40 cycles per degree even the brightest of bright lines and the darkest of dark lines cannot be seen.
The high spatial frequencies in an image give it its fine details.<ref>Blake, R., & Sekuler, R. (2006). Perception (5th ed.). New York: McGraw-Hill.</ref> Reducing the contrast of an image reduces the visibility of these high spatial frequencies because contrast sensitivity for them is already poor. This is how a reduction of contrast can reduce the clarity of an image—by removing its fine details.
It is important to emphasize that reducing the contrast is not the same as [[Focus (optics)|blurring]] an image. Blurring is accomplished by reducing the contrast only of the high spatial frequencies. Aerial perspective reduces the contrast of all spatial frequencies.
==In art==
In art, especially painting, ''aerial perspective'' refers to the technique of creating an illusion of depth by depicting distant objects as paler, less detailed, and usually bluer than near objects.
[[File:Frans Koppelaar - Backlight Langestraat.jpg|thumb|[[Frans Koppelaar]], Backlight Langestraat|left]] (One caution: in common speech, the words ''perspective'' and ''viewpoint'' tend to be used interchangeably; however, in art, aerial perspective does not imply an [[aerial viewpoint]], such as that forming the basis of the [[aerial landscape]] genre. The example by [[Frans Koppelaar]] pictured here shows the difference. This landscape is a good example of aerial perspective; however, it is not an aerial landscape, since the observer is apparently standing on the ground.)

The '''Armenian cochineal''' (''Porphyrophora hamelii'' <small>(Brandt)</small>), also known as the '''Ararat cochineal''' or '''Ararat scale''', is a [[scale insect]] indigenous to the [[Ararat plain]] and [[Aras River|Aras (Araks) River valley]] in the [[Armenian Highlands]]. It was formerly used to produce an [[eponym]]ous [[crimson]] [[carmine]] [[dye]]stuff known in [[Armenia]] as '''''vordan karmir''''' ({{lang-hy|[[wiktionary:որդան կարմիր|որդան կարմիր]]}}, literally "worm's red") and historically in [[Persia]] as ''kirmiz''.<ref name="ScaleNet_Porphyrophora_hamelii" /><ref name = "Ben-Dov_2005">{{cite book |last=Ben-Dov |first= Yair |date= 2005 |title= A Systematic Catalogue of the Scale Insect Family Magarodidae (Hemiptera: Coccoidea) of the World |location= United Kingdom |publisher= Intercept (Lavoisier) |isbn= 978-1-84585-000-5}}</ref><ref name = "Forbes_1964">{{cite book |last=Forbes |first= R.J. |date= 1964 |title= Studies in Ancient Technology |volume=IV |location= Leiden, Netherlands |publisher= E.J. Brill |isbn= 90-04-08307-3 |pages=102–103 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ua83AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA102#v=onepage&q&f=false|edition=2nd|orig-year=1956}}</ref><ref name="Donkin_1977">{{cite journal |last=Donkin |first=R.A. |date=1977 |title=The Insect Dyes of Western and West-Central Asia |jstor=40459185 |journal=Anthropos |publisher=Anthropos Institute |volume=72 |issue=5/6 |pages= 847–880 }}<!--|accessdate=9 October 2014--></ref><ref name="Vedeler_2014">{{cite book |last=Vedeler |first= Marianne |date= 2014 |title=Silk for the Vikings |location= Oxford, United Kingdom |publisher= OXBOW BOOKS |page= 52 |isbn= 978-1-78297-215-0}} Vedeler, citing Cardon (2007), notes that "the Persian name ''Kirmiz'' originally referred to the Armenian carmine, a parasitic insect living on Gramineae grass, but the same name was also used by Arab geographers for insects living on oak trees in Maghreb and Al-Andalus, probably referring to ''[[Kermes vermilio]]''", although "[i]t is ... not clear whether the 'Kirmiz' dyestuff mentioned in early Arab texts always refers to the use of the insect ''Kermes Vermilio''."</ref><ref name="Cardon_2007">{{cite book |last=Cardon |first= Dominique |date= 2007 |title= Natural Dyes: Sources, Tradition, Technology and Science |location= London, United Kingdom |publisher= Archetype Books |isbn= 978-1-904982-00-5}} English translation by Caroline Higgitt of Cardon's French-language book ''Le monde des teintures naturelles'' (Éditions Belin, Paris, 2003).</ref> The species is [[critically endangered]] within Armenia.<ref name="MNP_RA_P_ham">{{cite web |url=http://www.mnp.am/red_book_fauna/eng/a65.html |title=Porphyrophora ham melii Brandt, 1833 |last=Khachatryan |first=H. |website=Red Book of Armenia |publisher=Ministry of Nature Protection, Republic of Armenia |accessdate=9 October 2014}}</ref>
The Armenian cochineal scale insect, ''Porphyrophora hamelii'', is in a different [[Family (biology)|taxonomic family]] from the [[cochineal]] found in the [[Americas]]. Both insects produce red dyestuffs that are also commonly called cochineal.<ref name="Eastaugh_etal_2007">{{cite book |last1= Eastaugh |first1= Nicholas |last2= Walsh |first2= Valentine |last3= Chaplin |first3= Tracey |last4= Siddall |first4= Ruth |date= 2004 |title= Pigment Compendium: A Dictionary of Historical Pigments |location= Oxford, UK and Burlington, MA |publisher= Elsevier Butterwoth-Heinemann |isbn= 0-7506-5749-9 |pages=118–119 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2OH28vpzzMsC&pg=PA118#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=4 December 2015}}</ref>
== History and art == ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' is one of the ancient [[Natural dye|natural sources]] of red [[dye]] in the Middle East and Europe, along with the insect dyes [[Kermes (dye)|kermes]] (from ''[[Kermes vermilio]]'' and related species), [[lac]] (from ''[[Kerria lacca]]'' and related species), and [[carmine]] from other ''[[Porphyrophora]]'' species such as the [[Polish cochineal]] (''Porphyrophora polonica''), and the plant dye madder (from ''[[Rubia tinctorum]]'' and related species).<ref name = Forbes_1964 /><ref name="Donkin_1977" /><ref name="Cardon_2007" /><ref name="Robinson_1969">{{cite book |last=Robinson |first=Stuart |date=1969 |title=A History of Dyed Textiles |location=London, United Kingdom |publisher= Studio Vista |isbn=978-0-289-79644-3}}</ref><ref name="Bohmer_and_Thompson_1991">{{cite journal |last= Böhmer |first= Harald |last2= Thompson |first2=Jon |date=1991 |title=The Pazyryk Carpet: A Technical Discussion |jstor= 23203293 |journal=SOURCE: Notes in the History of Art |publisher= Ars Brevis Foundation |volume=10 |issue=4 |pages=30–36 }}<!--|accessdate=8 October 2014--></ref><ref name="Koren_2005">{{Citation |last= Koren |first= Zvi C. |date= 2005 |contribution=Chromatographic analyses of selected historic dyeings from ancient Israel |url= http://www.tekhelet.com/pdf/KOREN_2005_194-201.pdf |editor-last=Janaway | editor-first=R. |editor2-last= Wyeth |editor2-first=P. | title= Scientific Analysis of Ancient and Historic Textiles: Informing, Preservation, Display and Interpretation |location=London, United Kingdom |publisher= Archetype Publications |pages= 194–201 |accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="Cardon_2010">{{Citation |last= Cardon |first= Dominique |date= 2010 |contribution=Natural Dyes, Our Global Heritage of Colours |url= http://digitalcommons.unl.edu/tsaconf/12/ |title= Proceedings of the 12th Biennial Symposium of the Textile Society of America ("Textiles and Settlement: From Plains Space to Cyber Space") (October 6–9, 2010) |location=Lincoln, Nebraska, USA |publisher= [[Textile Society of America]] |issue=Paper 12}}</ref><ref name="Kirby_2011">{{Citation |last= Kirby |first= Jo |date= 2011 |contribution=Dyes, Dyeing and Lake Pigments – Historical Background |url= http://www.doernerinstitut.de/downloads/Back_to_the_Roots/Back_to_the_roots_Kirby_I.pdf |title= ''Back to the Roots'' – Workshop on the Preparation of Historical Lake Pigments (March 23–25, 2011) |location=Munich, Germany |publisher= Doerner Institut |issue=Session T10.2: Organic colorants in ancient and contemporary art |accessdate=9 October 2014}}</ref> It is possible that Armenian cochineal dye was in use as early as 714 B.C., when the [[Neo-Assyrian Empire|Neo-Assyrian]] king [[Sargon II]] was recorded as seizing red textiles as spoils of war from the kingdoms of [[Urartu]] (the geographic predecessor of Armenia) and Kilhu.<ref name = "Forbes_1964" /><ref name="Donkin_1977" /><ref name="Thureau-Dangin_1912">{{cite book |last=Thureau-Dangin |first= François |date= 1912 |title=Une Relation de la Hutième Campagne de Sargon (714 av. J.-C.) texte Assyrien inédit, publié et traduit |language=French |location= Paris, France |publisher= Librairie Paul Geuthner |page= 57 |url=https://archive.org/details/unerelationdelah00thuruoft |accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="Phipps_2010">{{cite book |last=Phipps |first= Elena |date= 2010 |title=Cochineal Red: The Art History of a Color {{Square bracket open|1}}adapted from The Metropolitan Museum of Art Bulletin, v. 67, no. 3 (Winter 2010){{Square bracket close|1}} |location= New York City and New Haven, USA and London, UK |publisher= The Metropolitan Museum of Art and Yale University Press |isbn=978-0-300-19560-6 |page= |url=http://www.metmuseum.org/research/metpublications/Cochineal_Red_the_art_history_of_a_color# |accessdate= 8 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="Kurdian_1941">{{cite journal |last=Kurdian |first=H. |date=1941 |title=Kirmiz |jstor= 594255 |journal=Journal of the American Oriental Society |publisher= American Oriental Society |volume=61 |issue=2 |pages=105–107 |doi=10.2307/594255}}<!--|accessdate=9 October 2014 --></ref> The [[Ancient Rome|Roman-era]] physician and pharmacologist [[Pedanius Dioscorides|Dioscorides]], writing in the 1st century A.D., noted that the best ''kokkos baphike'', the [[Quercus coccifera|kermes shrub]] and its "grain" ([[Kermes vermilio|kermes insect]]) that some ancient writers likely confused with ''Porphyrophora hamelii'', came from [[Galatia]] and Armenia.<ref name = "Forbes_1964" /><ref name="Donkin_1977" /><ref name="Dioscorides" >{{cite book |last=Obaldeston |first=T.A. |date=2000 |title=Dioscorides, ''De Materia Medica''. Five books in one volume: new modern English translation |location=Johannesburg, South Africa |publisher= IBIDIS Press |volume=4 |pages=588–591 |isbn=978-0-620-23435-1 |url=https://archive.org/details/de-materia-medica |accessdate=4 January 2015}} English translation by T.A. Obaldeston with introductory notes by R.P. Wood.</ref> In the [[Early Middle Ages]] the Armenian historians [[Ghazar Parpetsi]] and [[Movses Khorenatsi]] wrote specifically of a worm-produced dyestuff from the Ararat region.<ref name="Donkin_1977" /><ref name="Kurdian_1941" />
During the Middle Ages the Armenian cochineal dyestuff ''vordan karmir'', also known in Persia as ''kirmiz'', was widely celebrated in the [[Near East]].<ref name="Donkin_1977" /><ref name="Vedeler_2014" /><ref name="Cardon_2007" /><ref name="Kurdian_1941" /> ''Kirmiz'' is not to be confused with dyer's [[Kermes (dye)|kermes]], which was derived from another insect.<ref name="Cardon_2007" /> The Armenian cities [[Artashat (ancient city)|Artashat]] and [[Dvin (ancient city)|Dvin]] were early centers of the production of ''kirmiz'': during the 8th through 10th centuries [[Arabs|Arab]] and [[Persian people|Persian]] historians even referred to Artashat as "the town of ''kirmiz''".<ref name="Donkin_1977" /><ref name="Kurdian_1941" /> The Arabs and Persians regarded ''kirmiz'' as one of the most valuable commodities exported from Armenia.<ref name="Cardon_2007" /> The Armenians themselves used ''vordan karmir'' to produce dyes for [[textile]]s (including [[oriental rug]]s) and [[pigment]]s for [[Armenian illuminated manuscripts|illuminated manuscripts]] and church [[fresco]]s.<ref name="Donkin_1977" /><ref name="Kurdian_1941" /><ref name="Babenko_1988">{{cite journal |last=Babenko |first=Vitali |date=1988 |title=Vordan Karmir or Armenian Cochineal |url=http://www.rugreview.com/orr/8-5-40.htm |journal=Oriental Rug Review |publisher=Oriental Rug Auction Review |volume=VIII |issue=5 |pages=40–41 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130701123218/http://www.rugreview.com/orr/8-5-40.htm |archivedate=2013-07-01 |accessdate=9 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="Mushak_1988">{{cite journal |last=Mushak |first=Paul |date=1988 |title=The use of insect dyes in Oriental rugs and textiles: Some unresolved issues |url=http://www.rugreview.com/orr/8-5-33.htm |journal=Oriental Rug Review |publisher=Oriental Rug Auction Review |volume=VIII |issue=5 |pages=33–39 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130701123218/http://www.rugreview.com/orr/8-5-40.htm |archivedate=2013-07-01 |accessdate=9 October 2014}}</ref> Chemical analyses have identified the dye of ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' in [[Copts|Coptic]] textiles of the 3rd through 10th centuries, a [[Cashmere wool|cashmere]] cloth used in a [[kaftan]] from [[Sasanian Empire|Sassanid Persia]] in the 6th or 7th century, silk [[Episcopal gloves|liturgical gloves]] from 15th-century [[France]], [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] fabrics such as [[velvet]]s and [[lampas]] of the 15th through 17th centuries, and a 16th-century velvet [[cap of maintenance]] that belonged to [[Henry VIII of England]].<ref name="Cardon_2007" /><ref name="Petroviciu_etal_2012">{{cite journal |last1=Petroviciu |first1=Irina |last2=Crețu |first2=Ileana |last3=Vanden Berghe |first3=Ina |last4=Wouters |first4=Jan |last5=Medvedovici |first5=Andrei |last6=Albu |first6=Florin |last7=Creanga |first7=Doina |date=2012 |title=A discussion on the red anthraquinone dyes detected in historic textiles from Romanian collections |url=http://www.morana-rtd.com/e-preservationscience/2012/Petroviciu-29-02-2012.pdf |journal=e-Preservation Science |publisher=Morana RTD |volume=9 |pages=90–96 |accessdate=4 January 2015}}</ref><ref name="Waterford_Treasures">{{cite web|title=Henry VIII's Cap of Maintenance|url=http://www.waterfordtreasures.com/medieval-museum/whats-inside/king-henry-viiis-cap-of-maintenance|publisher=Treasures of Medieval Waterford, Ireland: Medieval Museum|accessdate=28 November 2015}}</ref>
At the time of the [[Renaissance]] in Europe, ''Porphyrophora'' insects were so valuable that in [[Constantinople]] during the 1430s, {{convert|1|kg|lb|abbr=off|spell=in}} of ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' insects was worth more than {{convert|5|g|oz|abbr=off}} of [[gold]].<ref name="Cardon_2007" /><ref name="Cardon_2000">{{Citation |last= Cardon |first= Dominique |date= 2000 |contribution=Du verme cremexe au veluto chremesino: une filierè vénitienne du cramoisi au XVe siécle |language=French |editor-last=Molà | editor-first=L. |editor2-last= Mueller |editor2-first=R.C. |editor3-last= Zanier |editor3-first=C. | title= ''La Seta in Italia dal Medioevo al Seicento'' |location=Venice, Italy |publisher= Fondazione Giorgio Cini |pages= 63–73}}</ref><ref name="Cardon_2007_note2">Some articles improperly cite Cardon to suggest, incorrectly, that Armenian cochineal insects were more valuable, by weight, than gold (i.e., one gram of insects was worth several grams of gold) during this era. Cardon (2007) does, however, note that according to the records of a [[Venice|Venetian]] merchant trading in Constantinople during the 1430s, even the cheapest Armenian cochineal insects were still worth more, pound-for-pound, than some live [[Slavery|slaves]] ([[Circassians|Circassian]] women and adolescents) that he had bought.</ref> The [[crimson]] ''Porphyrophora''-based dyes were especially prized in Europe for dyeing [[silk]], as the [[Scarlet (color)|scarlet]] dye [[Kermes (dye)|kermes]] was more plentiful, cheaper, and more effective for dyeing [[wool]]en textiles, which are heavier than silk and require more dye.<ref name="Cardon_2007" /> It has been estimated that on the order of a half million dried ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' insects were required to dye {{convert|1|kg|lb|spell=in}} of silk crimson during this period.<ref name="Cardon_2007" /><ref name="Cardon_2007_note3">400,000 to 560,000 dried ''P. hamelii'' insects were required to dye 1 kg of silk according to the figures of Cardon (2007): 1,000 g to 1,400 g of dried insects per 100 g of silk, with 40 adult females per gram of dried insects. Note that Virey (1840) reports 18,000–23,000 insects per 360-gram troy pound (50–64 insects per gram; not stated whether they were dried).</ref> On the comparison between Armenian and Polish cochineal, the author of a 15th-century treatise on silks in [[Florence]] wrote that "two pounds of the large {{Square bracket open|1}}Armenian cochineal insects{{Square bracket close|1}} will dye as much {{Square bracket open|1}}silk{{Square bracket close|1}} as one pound of small {{Square bracket open|1}}Polish cochineal insects{{Square bracket close|1}}; it is true that it gives a more noble and brighter colour than the small, but it gives less dye."<ref name="Cardon_2007" /><ref name="Gargiolli_1868_ed">{{cite book |editor-last=Gargiolli |editor-first=Girolamo |date=1868 |title=L'arte della seta in Firenze. Trattato del Secolo XV, pubblicato per la prima volta, e dialoghi raccolti da Girolamo Gargiolli. |language=Italian |location=Florence, Italy |publisher=G. Barbèra|page=32 |url=https://archive.org/details/lartedellasetai00garggoog |accessdate= 16 October 2014}}</ref>
Around the end of the 16th century the [[Old World]] ''Porphyrophora'' dyes were supplanted by dyes of the [[cochineal|''Dactylopius coccus'' cochineal]] species from the Americas, which could be harvested several times per year and yielded a much more concentrated dye.<ref name=Phipps_2010 />
The [[carmine]] dyestuff of ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' owes its red color almost entirely to [[carminic acid]], making it difficult to distinguish chemically from the dyestuff of [[cochineal]] from the Americas.<ref name="Cardon_2007" /><ref name="Robinson_1969" /><ref name="Bohmer_and_Thompson_1991" /><ref name=Phipps_2010 /><ref name="Wouters_and_Verhecken_1989">{{cite journal |last=Wouters |first=Jan |last2=Verhecken |first2=André |date=1989 |title=The Coccid Insect Dyes: HPLC and Computerized Diode-Array Analysis of Dyed Yarns |jstor=1506286 |journal=Studies in Conservation |publisher=Maney Publishing |volume=34 |issue=4 |pages=189–200 |doi=10.1179/sic.1989.34.4.189}}<!--|accessdate=10 October 2014 --></ref> The dyestuff of ''Porphyrophora polonica'' can be distinguished by its small admixture of kermesic acid, which is the major constituent of [[Kermes (dye)|kermes]] from ''Kermes vermilio''.
In 1833 the German naturalist [[Johann Friedrich von Brandt]] suggested the [[Binomial name|scientific name]] ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' after the Russian physician, traveler, and historian of German descent Iosif Khristianovich Gamel (Josef Hamel) ([[:ru:Гамель, Иосиф Христианович|ru]]), who visited the Ararat plain in the early 1830s and wrote a report about the "cochineal" insects living there.<ref name="Brandt_Ratzeburg_1833">{{cite book |last=Brandt |first=Johann Friedrich |last2= Ratzeburg |first2=Julius Theodor Christian |date=1833 |title=Medizinische Zoologie oder getreue Darstellung und Beschreibung der Thiere, in der Arzneimitellehre in Betracht kommen, in systematischer Folge herausgegeben. |language=German |location=Berlin, Germany |publisher=Trowitzsch and Sohn|volume=2 |page=356 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZQPnKys-3mkC&pg=PA356#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=11 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="Hamel_1833">{{Citation |last=Hamel |first=J. |date=1833 |contribution=Über Cochenille am Ararat und über Wurzelcochenille im Allgemeinen |contribution-url=http://publikationen.ub.uni-frankfurt.de/files/21947/E000014948.pdf |title=Mémoires de l'Académie Impériale des Sciences de St. Pétersbourg / Sciences mathématiques, physiques et naturelles |location=Frankfurt, Germany |publisher=Universitätsbibliothek Frankfurt am Main |language=German |volume=Tome III (1835) {{Square bracket open|1}}publishing the second part of Tome I (1833){{Square bracket close|1}} |issue=Série 6 |pages=9–64 |accessdate=11 October 2014}}. Publication of Hamel's 4 May 1833 report on the Ararat cochineal. Hamel's report mentions [[Johann Friedrich von Brandt|Brandt]].</ref>
<gallery mode="packed"> <!--Include photos of artwork (rugs, cloth, illuminated manuscripts, frescos, etc.) that have been definitively attributed to Armenian cochineal and not imported American or Polish cochineal, or kermes, madder, etc.--> File:Vordan Karmir (Cochineal Red) ornament on the ceiling of S. Grigor Chapel, Noravank monastery.jpg|''Vordan karmir'' ceiling art at [[Noravank|Noravank Monastery]] File:Խաչքար Գեղարդ27.JPG|''[[Khachkar]]s'' (cross-stones) at [[Geghard|Geghard Monastery]] painted with ''vordan karmir''<ref name="Geghard_Armenian_Monuments">{{cite web|title=Geghard 7: Monk cells, Khachkar Wall. Geghard's Khachkars.|url=http://www.armenianheritage.org/en/monument/Geghard/78|publisher=Armenian Monuments Awareness Project|accessdate=12 October 2014|quote=The red color found on some of the cross stones is a result of their being painted with Vortan Karmir, a red dye made from beetles native to Armenia. The red dye was among the more famous exports of the kingdom, and was valued more than gold in Europe and the Near East. Its resilience has long since proved itself; the color you see now is more than 800 years old.}}</ref> File:Saint Bertrand de Comminges-Gants et Chaussons.jpg|Silk [[Episcopal gloves|liturgical gloves]] (left) of [[Pierre de Foix, le vieux|Cardinal Pierre de Foix]] (15th century), dyed crimson with ''P. hamelii'' carmine<ref name="Cardon_2007" /> File:Armenian Stamp Karmin.jpg|A 2006 Armenian postage stamp depicting ''P. hamelii'' </gallery>
== Biology == [[File:Porphyrophora hamelii, cysts.jpg|thumb|''Porphyrophora hamelii'' cysts around the root of ''Aeluropus littoralis'']]
''Porphyrophora hamelii'' is a [[Sexual dimorphism|sexually dimorphic]] species.<ref name="Vahedi_and_Hodgson_2007">{{cite journal |last= Vahedi |first= Hassan-Ali |last2= Hodgson |first2= C.J. |date= 2007 |title=Some species of the hypogeal scale insect Porphyrophora Brandt (Hemiptera: Sternorrhyncha: Coccoidea: Margarodidae) from Europe, the Middle East and Africa |journal= Systematics and Biodiversity |publisher= Taylor & Francis |volume= 5 |issue= 1 |pages= 23–122 |doi=10.1017/s1477200006002039}}<!--|accessdate=9 October 2014 --></ref><ref name="Foldi_2005">{{cite journal |last= Foldi |first= Imre |date= 2005 |title=Ground pearls: a generic revision of the Margarodidae ''sensu stricto'' (Hemiptera: Sternorrhyncha: Coccoidea) |url= http://zoologie.umh.ac.be/asef/pdf/2005_41_01/compact/Foldi_ASEF_2005_41_1_81_125_compact.pdf |journal= Annales de la Société Entomologique de France |series=New Series |publisher= Taylor & Francis |volume=41 |issue= 1 |pages= 81–125 |accessdate=9 October 2014 |doi=10.1080/00379271.2005.10697442}}</ref><ref name= "Jakubski_1965">{{cite book |last=Jakubski |first=Antoni Władysław |date= 1965 |title=A Critical Revision of the Families Margarodidae and Termitococcidae (Hemiptera, Coccoidea) |location=London, United Kingdom |publisher=Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History)}}</ref> The adult female, from which [[carmine]] is extracted, is oval-shaped, soft-bodied, crimson in color, and has large forelegs for [[Fossorial|digging]]. The females can be quite large for a ''Porphyrophora'' species: up to {{convert|10|–|12|mm|in|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|7|mm|in|abbr=on}} wide.<ref name="Vahedi_and_Hodgson_2007" /><ref name= "Jakubski_1965" /> It has been noted that one [[Troy weight|troy pound]] (360 grams) of cochineal insects requires 18,000–23,000 specimens of ''Porphyrophora hamelii'', but 100,000–130,000 specimens of the sister species [[Polish cochineal|''Porphyrophora polonica'']] (or 20,000–25,000 specimens of [[Cochineal|''Dactylopius coccus'']]).<ref name="Virey_1840">{{Citation |last= Virey |first= M.J.J. |date= 1840 |contribution= Remarks on the former uses of purple or scarlet colouring insects. New cochineal of Persia and Armenia. |editor-last=Watt |contribution-url= https://books.google.com/books?id=LKQwAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA209#v=onepage&q&f=false |editor-first= Charles |editor2-last= Watt, Jr. |editor2-first= John |title= The Chemist: Or, Reporter of Chemical Discoveries and Improvements, and Protector of the Rights of the Chemist and Chemical Manufacturer |location= London, United Kingdom |publisher= R. Hastings |volume= I |pages= 209–210}}</ref><ref name="Fennel_1842">{{Citation |last= Fennel |first= James H. |date= 1842 |contribution= On useful insects and their products |contribution-url= https://books.google.com/books?id=wTo5AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA295#v=onepage&q&f=false |editor-last= Watt | editor-first= Charles |editor2-last= Watt, Jr. |editor2-first= John |title= The Mirror of Literature, Amusement, and Instruction |location=London, United Kingdom |publisher= J. Limbird |volume= I |issue= 19 |pages= 295–296}}</ref> The adult male ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' is a winged insect.
The life cycle of ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' is mostly [[Hypogeal|subterranean]].<ref name="MNP_RA_P_ham" /><ref name="Vahedi_and_Hodgson_2007" /><ref name="Foldi_2005" /> Newly hatched [[Nymph (biology)|nymphs]] emerge from the ground in the springtime and crawl until they find the [[root]]s of certain [[Poaceae|grassy plants]] that [[Halophyte|grow in saline soil]], such as [[Aeluropus|''Aeluropus littoralis''<!-- <small>(Gouan) Parl.</small>-->]] ({{lang-hy|որդանխոտ}} (genus ''Aeluropus''),<ref name="Babenko_1988" /><ref name="Sov_Arm_Encyc_Orient_Rug_Rev">{{cite journal |date=1988 |title=Vordan Karmir: The Red Worm (From the ''Soviet Armenia Encyclopedia'', Vol. 8, 1982, pp. 642–43) |url=http://www.rugreview.com/orr/8-5-42.htm |journal=Oriental Rug Review |publisher=Oriental Rug Auction Review |volume=VIII |issue=5 |pages=42–43 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130701164358/http://www.rugreview.com/orr/8-5-42.htm |archivedate=2013-07-01 |accessdate=9 October 2014}}</ref> literally "worm's grass") and the common reed [[Phragmites|''Phragmites australis''<!-- <small>(Cav.) Trin. ex Steud.</small>-->]].<ref name="MNP_RA_P_ham" /><ref name="Vahedi_and_Hodgson_2007" /> The nymphs continue to feed on these roots throughout the spring and summer, forming protective [[pearl]]-like cysts in the process.<!--<ref name = "Ben-Dov_2005" /><ref name="Vahedi_and_Hodgson_2007" /><ref name="Foldi_2005" /><ref name="MNP_RA_P_ham" />--> From mid-September to mid-October adults emerge from the ground between 5 a.m. and 10 a.m. to mate.<ref name="Cardon_2007" /><ref name="MNP_RA_P_ham" /><ref name="Sov_Arm_Encyc_Orient_Rug_Rev" /><ref name="Cardon_2007_note4">Cardon (2007) cites her own field mission in Armenia in 1989 as well as the papers by Jakubski (1965) and Mktrtchian and Sarkisov (1985) for her description of ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' biology, which states that the mating time is from 5 a.m. to 10 a.m. The ''Soviet Armenian Encyclopedia'' (1982) and the online ''Red Book of Armenia'' (which cites Mktchyan and Sarkisov (1985) and others) state that the mating time is from 6 a.m. to 11 a.m. Note that in 1982 and 1985 the emergence of the insects in early September would have been in Armenian Summer Time (UTC+5), whereas the Republic of Armenia has been on UTC+4 time year-round since 2012.</ref> The adult insects, lacking mouthparts, do not feed.<ref name="Foldi_2005" /> Adult males live for only a few days, but adult females can live longer, burrowing into the ground to lay their eggs.<ref name="Foldi_2005" />
== Habitat and conservation == [[File:Vordan Karmir Habitat.jpg|thumb|left|The historic habitat of ''Porphyrophora hamelii''. [[Vordan Karmir State Reservation]] is in red and the historic dye-producing cities [[Artashat (ancient city)|Artashat]] and [[Dvin (ancient city)|Dvin]] are in purple.]]
The red dye-producing insects of the Ararat plain were once plentiful: a 19th-century French traveler wrote that shepherds' flocks, when led to drink from the [[Aras River|Araxes (Araks) River]], would appear bloody from the insects.<ref name="Donkin_1977" /> In the mid-20th century the extent of occurrence in Armenia was {{convert|100|km2|abbr=on}} with a recorded distribution that included the [[Ararat Province|Ararat]] and [[Armavir Province|Armavir]] provinces in Armenia as well as the Turkish, Iranian, and Russian [[Caucasus]], but by the 1990s the extent of occurrence in Armenia had shrunk to about {{convert|20|km2|abbr=on}}, mostly in Armavir Province.<ref name="MNP_RA_P_ham" /><ref name="Vahedi_and_Hodgson_2007" /><ref name="REC-Caucasus_Armavir">{{cite web |url=http://www.rec-caucasus.org/Flash/PDF/AR/AR7.pdf |title=Political Administrative Region (marz): Armavir |website= Regional Environmental Center for the Caucasus (REC Caucasus) |accessdate=10 October 2014}}</ref> During the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] period, [[desalination]] of the Armenian salt marshes to create "economic and agricultural regions", and the creation of lakes for [[Fishery|fisheries]], "severely restricted the {{Square bracket open|1}}habitable{{Square bracket close|1}} area for the insects and {{Square bracket open|1}}endangered their{{Square bracket close|1}} existence."<ref name="Sov_Arm_Encyc_Orient_Rug_Rev"/>
[[File:Vordan Karmir reserve.jpg|thumb|[[Vordan Karmir State Reservation]], Armenia]]
The population in Armenia resides almost entirely in the [[Vordan Karmir State Reservation]], a [[salt marsh|salt meadow]] habitat of {{convert|198.33|ha|abbr=on}} northwest of [[Arazap|Arazap village]] and {{convert|21.52|ha|abbr=on}} in the north of [[Jrarat, Armavir|Jrarat village]] established in 1987 near the Araks River border with [[Turkey]], plus a site southeast of [[Ararat (village), Armenia|Ararat village]] and a few patches of several [[hectare]]s elsewhere.<ref name="MNP_RA_P_ham" /><ref name="Vordan_Karmir_Reservation_Statute_2003">{{cite web |url=http://www.arlis.am/DocumentView.aspx?DocID=48076 |script-title=hy:«Որդան Կարմիր» Պետական Արգելավայրի Կանոնադրությունը Հաստատելու Մասին |trans-title="Vordan Karmir" State Reservation Statute of Approval|date=July 12, 2003 |website=Armenian Legal Information System (ARLIS.am) |publisher=Government of the Republic of Armenia |accessdate=10 October 2014|quote=1. «Որդան կարմիր» պետական արգելավայրը (այսուհետ` արգելավայր) ստեղծվել է Հայկական Սովետական Սոցիալիստական Հանրապետության Մինիստրների խորհրդի 1987 թվականի փետրվարի 2-ի N 61 որոշմամբ` Հայաստանի Հանրապետության Արմավիրի մարզի աղուտ հողերի վրա: Արգելավայրն զբաղեցնում է 219.85 հեկտար տարածք, բաղկացած է երկու առանձին տեղամասերից` Արազափի գյուղական համայնքի հյուսիսարևմտյան մասում (198.33 հեկտար) և Ջրառատի գյուղական համայնքի հյուսիսային մասում (21.52 հեկտար)` Արարատյան հարթավայրում, ծովի մակերևույթից 835–850 մետր բարձրության վրա:|language=Armenian }}</ref><ref name="Hayastani_Azgayin_Atlas_A">{{Citation |date= 2007 |contribution= Էնդեմիկ Տեսակներ: Կենդանիներ [''Endemic Species: Animals''] |script-title=hy:Հայաստանի Ազգային Ատլաս |trans-title=Armenian National Atlas |location= Yerevan, Armenia |publisher= "Geodeziayi ev Kʻartezagrutʻyan Kentron" POAK |volume= I |isbn= 99941-0-176-5 |pages= 83 |url= http://www.cadastre.am/resources/atlasA/images/83.jpg |accessdate= 3 January 2015 |language= Armenian}}</ref> There have been no recent scientific reports on populations of ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' outside the surroundings of Mount Ararat.<ref name="Cardon_2007"/>
''Porphyrophora hamelii'' is considered [[critically endangered]] within Armenia by meeting the following conditions: an [[Occupancy–abundance relationship#Measures of species geographic range|area of occupancy]] of less than {{convert|10|km2|abbr=on}}, plus severely fragmented occupancy or known to exist at only a single location, plus continued decline (observed, inferred, or projected) in the area of occurrence, area of occupancy, and area, extent, and/or quality of habitat; and an [[Occupancy–abundance relationship#Measures of species geographic range|extent of occurrence]] of less than {{convert|100|km2|abbr=on}} with the aforementioned conditions of continued decline.<ref name="MNP_RA_P_ham" /><ref name="IUCN_Red_List_Categories_Criteria_v3_1">{{cite report|date=9 February 2000 |title=IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria, Version 3.1, Second Edition |url=http://jr.iucnredlist.org/documents/redlist_cats_crit_en.pdf |publisher=International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Species Survival Commission |pages=16–17 |accessdate=10 October 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128190606/http://jr.iucnredlist.org/documents/redlist_cats_crit_en.pdf |archivedate=28 January 2016 }}</ref>
Threats to the ''Porphyrophora hamelii'' population in Armenia include the [[Land development|development of saline lands]], agricultural improvements, uncontrolled [[livestock]] grazing, and possibly [[climate change]].<ref name="MNP_RA_P_ham" /> Natural foes of the species include [[Tyrophagus putrescentiae|mold mites]], [[Coccinellidae|lady beetles]]<!--Lithophilus (or Tetrabrachys) bipustulatus (see also [[wikispecies:Lithophilus]]) and Nephus bipunctatus (see also [[Nephus]])-->, [[harvester ant]]s<!--Messor rufitarsis and Messor caducus (see also [[Messor]]), Pheidole pallidula (see also [[Pheidole]])-->, and [[erratic ant]]s<!--Tapinoma (or Formica) erraticum (or erraticus, erratica)-->.<ref name="ScaleNet_Porphyrophora_hamelii" /><ref name = "Ben-Dov_2005" />

'''The Art Museum Partnership''' (2005–2012) was a [[New York City]]-based [[non-profit organization]] that provided the nonprofit [[art museum]]s with educational opportunities that facilitate the sharing of information, resources, and collections. The Partnership was primarily established to benefit the small to medium-sized museums that comprise the largest segment in the field. However, larger museums were encouraged to participate, since the challenges in the field are universal and all participants benefit from the knowledge of their peers. The Art Museum Partnership was open to the leaders of all nonprofit art institutions regardless of size or focus.
'''The Directors Forum''' was the signature program of the Art Museum Partnership. The two-and-a-half-day annual conference for museum directors featured panel discussions with some of the most distinguished professionals in the art world. It was held October at renowned museums and cultural institutions in New York City. The goal of this annual conference was to engage museum leaders throughout the nation in an exchange of views on issues of mutual concern.

page.title: Art and politics in post-2011 Tunisia

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Sidebar|navbar=off |image = [[File:Tunisian revolution graffiti.JPG|frameless]] |caption = Graffiti in central Tunis on 28 January 2012 |pretitle = Part of a series on |title = [[Culture of Tunisia]] |heading1 = Art and politics in post-2011 Tunisia |content1 = {{flatlist| * [[Arab Spring]] * [[Tunisia]] * [[Tunisian revolution]] * [[Tunis]] }}}}
The [[culture of Tunisia]] is thousands of years old, but the 2011 [[Tunisian revolution]] brought about important changes to the way art and politics interact in [[Tunisia]]. Censorship under the dictatorship of former president [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali]] was replaced with unprecedented freedom of expression and questions on how to use it.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rhodes|first=Emile|title=La culture tunisienne fait sa révolution|url=http://www.slateafrique.com/1763/culture-tunisienne-fait-revolution|accessdate=20 April 2013|newspaper=Slate Afrique|date=11 May 2011}}</ref> The newfound vigorousness of the arts in Tunisia and the new challenges artists have to address echo those in other countries affected by the [[Arab Spring]], especially [[Egypt]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Demerdash|first=Nancy|title=Consuming Revolution: Ethics, Art, and Ambivalence in the Arab Spring|url=http://www.brismes.ac.uk/nmes/consuming-revolutionethics-art-and-ambivalence-in-the-arab-spring#1|publisher=British Society for Middle Eastern Studies|accessdate=20 April 2013}}</ref>
==Background==
===Art before the Tunisian revolution===
Artists found ways to circumvent or avoid censorship of their work before the downfall of Zine El Abidine Ben Ali's regime.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rhodes|first=Emile|title=Quand les artistes se jouaient de Ben Ali|url=http://www.slateafrique.com/1665/les-arts-pour-contourner-censure-ben-ali|accessdate=17 April 2013|newspaper=Slate Afrique|date=11 May 2011}}</ref> [[Tunisian collaborative painting]], for instance, is an art form created in Tunisia during the 1980s that allows several artists to collaborate on one piece without prior discussion or planning. Although the Tunisian art market was relatively small and inward looking compared to the ones in other North African countries like [[Morocco]] or [[Algeria]], there was proof of an evolving, dynamic art scene even before the revolution, with the successes of [http://galerie-elmarsa.com/ang/index.html Galerie El Marsa] or [http://www.leviolonbleu.com/ Le Violon Bleu].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ben Soltane|first=Mohamed|title=Art in Tunisia: a visibility in the making|date=14 September 2010|url=https://www.academia.edu/617582/Art_in_Tunisia_A_visibility_in_the_making|accessdate=19 April 2013}}</ref>
Still, according to Khadija Hamdi: "In Tunisia, with the absence, among other things, of a cultural policy specific to the art market, and the lack of the appropriate cultural and ideological conditions, the emergence of a "system" of "contemporary art" itself (in the Western sense) has not yet been possible."<ref>{{cite web|last=Hamdi|first=Khadija|title=On the path of contemporary Tunisian art|url=http://www.ismailbahri.lautre.net/files/on-the-path-of-tunisian-art-en-2011.pdf|accessdate=19 April 2013}}</ref>
Certain artistic institutions such as the school of music in [[El Kef]] were closed by the regime as potential hotbeds of discord.
===Art during and after the Tunisian revolution===
Works of art that used the revolution as a subject proliferated after the downfall of the former regime, both to emulate iconic revolutionary symbols and to explore the complex challenges the country still faced.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Shilton|first=Siobhán|title=Art and the ‘Arab Spring’: Aesthetics of revolution in contemporary Tunisia|journal=French Cultural Studies|date=29 January 2013|volume=24|issue=1|pages=129–145|doi=10.1177/0957155812464166|url=http://frc.sagepub.com/content/24/1/129|accessdate=18 April 2013}}</ref> The revolution saw an upshot in the number of artistic manifestations such as exhibits, most notably in the field of [[photography]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Triki|first=Rachida|title=Tunisia: A Dynamic and Vigilant Art Scene|url=http://universes-in-universe.org/eng/nafas/articles/2012/tunisia_art_scene|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=Nafas Art Magazine|date=February 2012}}</ref> Other art forms such as music also thrived after the revolution.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kraft|first=Jessica C.|title=After the revolution, arts bloom in Tunisia|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/The-Culture/Music/2012/0209/After-the-revolution-arts-bloom-in-Tunisia|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=The Christian Science Monitor|date=9 February 2012}}</ref>
Remnants from the older regime and from the demonstrations themselves were also used by artists during the revolution, by transforming a police station into an art gallery or transforming burnt out cars into works of art, for instance.<ref>{{cite news|last=Metwaly|first=Ati|title=Police station in Tunisia turned into an art gallery|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/5/35/20023/Arts--Culture/Stage--Street/Police-station-in-Tunisia-turned-into-an-art-galle.aspx|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=Ahram Online|date=30 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Ben Miled|first=Zied|title=Burnt out cars turned into artistic pieces in Tunisian revolution|url=http://www.demotix.com/news/1580613/burnt-out-cars-turned-artistic-pieces-tunisian-revolution#media-1580588|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=Demotix|date=21 March 2011}}</ref> Villas belonging to the Trabelsis, the family of Zine El Abidine Ben Ali's wife [[Leïla Ben Ali]], became the target of graffiti artists soon after the regime's downfall.<ref>{{cite news|title=Les graffeurs tunisiens s'invitent dans les villas Trabelsi|url=http://www.slateafrique.com/8285/des-graffeurs-tunisiens-tagguent-les-villas-des-trabelsi|accessdate=20 April 2013|newspaper=Slate Afrique|date=6 July 2011}}</ref>
====Street art====
In the months during and following the revolution, [[street art]] played a major role by reclaiming public spaces that used to be controlled by the government and by letting artists and ordinary citizens express themselves freely for the first time in years.<ref>{{cite news|last=Galliot|first=Lorena|title=Graffiti artists show their support for the Tunisian revolution|url=http://observers.france24.com/content/20110606-graffiti-artists-show-support-tunisian-revolution|accessdate=18 April 2013|newspaper=France 24|date=6 June 2011}}</ref> Individual artists or groups like the student-run Ahl El Kahf collective used stencils, graffitis and paintings to depict political or revolutionary themes, such as the portrait of [[Mohamed Bouazizi]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Galliot|first=Lorena|title=Graffiti artists show their support for the Tunisian revolution|url=http://observers.france24.com/content/20110606-graffiti-artists-show-support-tunisian-revolution|accessdate=18 April 2013|newspaper=France 24|date=6 June 2011}}</ref> In addition to using local revolutionary symbols, street artists also reused Western and Latin American revolutionary icons in the work.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rodrigues|first=Jill|title=Revolutionary Art on the Streets of Tunisia|url=http://pdq.rwu.edu/news/revolutionary-art-streets-tunisia|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=Roger Williams University|date=4 April 2013}}</ref> Murals were one of the most common form of street art, representing, for instance, people killed during the revolution.<ref>{{cite web|last=Letsinger|first=Brandon|title=Creating the Political: Street Art after the Tunisia Revolution|url=http://letsingerwrites.com/2011/10/29/creating-the-political-art-after-revolution-part-1/|accessdate=19 April 2013}}</ref>
According to Nicholas Korody, "The graffiti of the Tunisian revolution always possesses a revolutionary character in form. That is to say, it existed as a reappropriation of authoritarian-controlled property. It is also notable in that it is the only art form born out of the revolution. While a few artists existed in Tunisia during the Ben Ali regime, their work was quickly covered up and few people knew about the art form. Since the revolution, it has grown massively."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Korody|first=Nicholas|title=The Revolutionary Art: Street Art Before and After the Tunisian Revolution|journal=Independent Study Project|date=7 December 2011|url=http://digitalcollections.sit.edu/isp_collection/1134|accessdate=19 April 2013}}</ref>
'''Academic Response'''
The revolution in Tunisia and its aftermath has prompted much discussion. Tunisian intellectual, Dr. Mohamed-Salah Omri, a fellow at University of Oxford in Modern Arabic literature, has dedicated much of his research to examining the intersections between [https://www.academia.edu/5200885/A_Revolution_of_Dignity_and_Poetry poetry and revolution], the [https://www.academia.edu/30462852/Confluency_tarafud_between_trade_unionism_culture_and_revolution_in_Tunisia "Confluency"] between Culture, Revolution and [https://www.academia.edu/5208539/Trade_Unions_and_the_construction_of_a_specifically_Tunisian_protest_configuration Trade Unionism in Tunisia],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Omri|first=Mohamed-Salah|title=Trade Unions and the construction of a specifically Tunisian protest configuration|url=https://www.academia.edu/5208539/Trade_Unions_and_the_construction_of_a_specifically_Tunisian_protest_configuration|language=en}}</ref> and the overall challenges of [https://www.academia.edu/9808087/Tunisias_revolution_of_dignity_and_freedom_cannot_be_colour-codedhttp_www.tni.org_article_tunisia-revolution-dignity-and-freedom-can-not-be-colour-coded the democratic transition in the country].
==New challenges==
===Religious challenges to artistic freedom===
Despite the end of Zine El Abidine Ben Ali's dictatorship, Tunisian artists have faced new challenges to their artistic freedom, often from groups that have a strict interpretation of [[Islam]]. After years of censorship and repression of both the art world and religious identity, the new regime has had to juggle between the two, and tensions have periodically surfaced.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tunisian artists use graffiti to fight religious extremism|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/09/07/236596.html|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=Reuters|date=7 September 2012}}</ref>
In June 2012 riots erupted against the "Printemps des Arts" exhibit in [[La Marsa]] that [[Salafi]] groups and others deemed blasphemous, most notably because of one work of art that spelled out [[God]]'s name using insects. Hundreds were arrested and curfews were imposed.<ref>{{cite news|last=Amara|first=Tarek|title=Islamists riot over "insulting" art|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2012/06/12/uk-tunisia-salafis-clash-idUKBRE85B0XP20120612|accessdate=18 April 2013|newspaper=Reuters|date=12 June 2012|author2=Lin Noueihed}}</ref> Some radical religious leaders called for the deaths of the artists, who received death threats, and Tunisian minister of culture [[Mehdi Mabrouk]] condemned the artists by saying that art should be "beautiful," not "revolutionary," and that the artists were wrong to invoke Islamic imagery.<ref>{{cite news|last=Larkins|first=Zoe|title=Under New Regime, Tunisian Artists Face New Censorship|url=http://www.artinamericamagazine.com/news-opinion/news/2012-06-26/tunisia-censorship/|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=Art in America|date=26 June 2012}}</ref> The leader of the ruling [[Ennahda Movement]], [[Rachid Ghannouchi]], said that he condemned violence against individuals or property but also opposed "attacks on the beliefs of Tunisians" and emphasized the need to protect "sacred symbols".<ref>{{cite news|last=Ryan|first=Yasmine|title=Tunisia's embattled artists speak out|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2012/06/2012615111819112421.html|accessdate=18 April 2013|newspaper=Al Jazeera|date=15 June 2012}}</ref> Also deemed blasphemous by some was a work of art by Nadia Jelassi, who created an installation of female mannequin busts, cloaked in [[hijab]]s and surrounded by stones. Jelassi, a teacher at the [[Tunis Institute of Fine Arts]], was called to appear before a judge and was charged for disturbing public order.<ref>{{cite news|last=Beardsley|first=Eleanor|title=Tunisians Battle Over The Meaning Of Free Expression|url=https://www.npr.org/2012/09/28/161906865/tunisians-battle-over-the-meaning-of-free-expression|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=NPR|date=28 September 2012}}</ref> Her treatment - police took her fingerprints and a mugshot - sparked an online campaign in defense of free expression.<ref>{{cite news|last=Weslaty|first=Lilia|title=Tunisia: Artists on the offensive with photo campaign|url=http://nawaat.org/portail/2012/09/10/tunisia-artists-on-the-offensive-with-photo-campaign/|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=Nawaat|date=10 September 2012}}</ref> In the aftermath of the incident, the artistic community complained that authorities weren't doing enough to protect them.<ref>{{cite news|last=Harris|first=Gareth|title=After Islamist riots triggered by contemporary art fair, tensions remain high in Tunis|url=http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/After-Islamist-riots-triggered-by-contemporary-art-fair-tensions-remain-high-in-Tunis-/26913|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=The Art Newspaper|date=11 July 2012}}</ref>
Religious hardliners tried and sometimes succeeded to prevent other artistic events from taking place like music festivals and plays.<ref>{{cite news|last=Amara|first=Tarek|title=Tunisian artists cry for help against religious extremists|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/09/19/us-tunisia-salafi-art-idUSBRE88I0SM20120919|accessdate=18 April 2013|newspaper=Reuters|date=19 September 2012}}</ref> Women artists in particular feared that hardline Muslim pressure would prevent them from working freely.<ref>{{cite news|last=Dettmer|first=Jamie|title=Tunisia's Female Artists Fear Islamist Repression|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/tunisia-female-artist-fear-islamist-repression/1617944.html|accessdate=18 April 2013|newspaper=Voice of America|date=8 March 2013}}</ref>
These tensions led many to feel that "nothing had changed" with regards to the relations between art and politics, as censorship is said to have shifted from being political to being religious and moral.<ref>{{cite news|last=Jurich|first=Joscelyn|title=Revolution Hasn’t Changed Artistic Censorship in Tunisia|url=http://hyperallergic.com/63757/revolution-hasnt-changed-artistic-censorship-in-tunisia/|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=Hyperallergic|date=18 January 2013}}</ref> According to Sofiane Ouissi, co-creative director of the Dream City, an art festival that takes place in Tunis' medina: "Under the old censorship and oppression - it was conspicuous; we could locate it; it was clear for us. [...] But now, since it was displaced, it has come into the public space, you never know where dictatorship is going to emerge."<ref>{{cite news|last=Fordham|first=Alice|title=The battle for Tunisia's art and soul|url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/world/africa/the-battle-for-tunisias-art-and-soul#full|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=The National|date=2 October 2012}}</ref>
===Political challenges to artistic freedom===
Artists have also been targeted by the new regime. In November 2012, Chahine Berriche and Oussama Bouagila, two Tunisian graffiti artists, were arrested for writing "the people want rights for the poor" and "the poor are the living-dead in Tunisia" on the wall of a university. The two artists were members of the Zwelwa<ref>{{cite news|last=Hendoud |first=Henda |title=Tunisie – Zwewla, le graffiti se révolte |url=http://blog.slateafrique.com/tawa-fi-tunis/2012/11/19/tunisie-%E2%80%93-zewla-le-graffiti-se-revolte/ |accessdate=20 April 2013 |newspaper=Slate Afrique |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121122053405/http://blog.slateafrique.com/tawa-fi-tunis/2012/11/19/tunisie-%E2%80%93-zewla-le-graffiti-se-revolte/ |archivedate=22 November 2012 }}</ref> art activist collective and were charged with breaching the state of emergency, writing on public property and disturbing public order.<ref>{{cite news|last=Ajmi|first=Sana|title=Tunisian graffiti artists targeted by law|url=http://www.opendemocracy.net/sana-ajmi/tunisian-graffiti-artists-targeted-by-law|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=Open Democracy|date=16 December 2012}}</ref>
===Attempts to address challenges===
Tunisian street artists [[eL Seed]] reacted to these tensions between the artistic and religious communities by painting verses of the [[Quran]] preaching tolerance onto the Jara [[mosque]] in his hometown of [[Gabès]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Davies|first=Catriona|title=Tunisian artist graffitis minaret, fights intolerance|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/09/19/world/meast/el-seed-grafitti-minaret|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=CNN|date=20 September 2012}}</ref> He also said that the threat of censorship was exaggerated in certain circles: "I feel that there is a lot of hypocrisy in Tunisia at the moment, and unfortunately many artists relish censorship, or the fear of it, if it brings them international recognition. I personally have not felt any real threats of censorship."<ref>{{cite news|last=Rao|first=Mallika|title=El Seed On Graffiti, Censorship In Tunisia, And Why Arabic Is An Artist's Best Friend|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/09/27/el-seed-tunisian-graffiti-artist_n_1918493.html|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=The Huffington Post|date=30 September 2012}}</ref>
==New art institutions and organizations==
The [http://www.bchirartcenter.com/ B’chira Art Center], located near [[Sidi Thabet]] between [[Tunis]] and [[Bizerte]], opened in July 2011. The center aimed to develop contemporary art by providing a space for artists to produce and show work, as well as an experimental laboratory to research techniques and introduce children to the art world.<ref>{{cite news|last=Ben Zineb |first=Sayda |title=Un lieu où se développent les pratiques artistiques contemporaines |url=http://www.letemps.com.tn/article-57952.html |accessdate=19 April 2013 |newspaper=Le Temps |date=31 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801091812/http://www.letemps.com.tn/article-57952.html |archivedate=1 August 2013 }}</ref>
The [[Carthage National Museum]] saw the launch of an umbrella program called [http://www.carthagecontemporary.com/ Carthage Contemporary], part of an increasingly dynamic contemporary art scene in Tunisia.<ref>{{cite news|last=Milliard|first=Coline|title=From the Ashes of Tunisia's Revolution, A Contemporary Art Scene Grows: A Q&A With Curator Khadija Hamdi|url=http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/805447/from-the-ashes-of-tunisias-revolution-a-contemporary-art-scene-grows-a-qa-with-curator-khadija-hamdi|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=Artinfo UK|date=22 May 2012}}</ref>
Also established after the revolution in 2011 was the Tunisian Federation of the Visual Arts (Fédération Tunisienne des Arts Plastiques), a grouping of young artist associations aimed at defending and promoting visual arts in Tunisia. These goals are shared by two preexisting organizations, the Association of Tunisian Visual Artists (Union des Artistes Plasticiens Tunisiens) and the Union of Visual Arts Professions (Syndicat des Métiers des Arts Plastiques), created in 2009.<ref>{{cite news|last=Triki|first=Rachida|title=Tunisia: A Dynamic and Vigilant Art Scene|url=http://universes-in-universe.org/eng/nafas/articles/2012/tunisia_art_scene|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=Nafas Art Magazine|date=February 2012}}</ref>
==International influences and projects==
===In Tunisia===
French street artist and photographer [[JR (artist)|JR]] launched the first phase of his [[Inside Out Project]] in Tunisia, where native photographers displayed large scale portraits of ordinary Tunisians around the country instead of the formerly ubiquitous pictures of the president.<ref>{{cite web|title=Artocracy in Tunisia|url=http://www.jr-art.net/projects/artocracy-in-tunisia|publisher=JR|accessdate=18 April 2013}}</ref> The project fostered discussion with Tunisians, some of whom understood and appreciated the project, while others did not think art should play a political role by using public spaces and complained that the previous regime already imposed pictures upon them all the time.<ref>{{cite news|last=Ryan|first=Yasmine|title=Art challenges Tunisian revolutionaries|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2011/03/201132223217876176.html|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=Al Jazeera|date=26 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Bell|first=Melissa|title=Tunisia and the art revolution|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/blogpost/post/tunisia-and-the-art-revolution/2011/03/25/AFhnT5WB_blog.html|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=25 March 2011}}</ref>
Algerian-French artist ZOO Project also celebrated the revolution by placing hundreds of life-size figures around the city, representing the Tunisians who revolted and in particular those who died during the revolution.<ref>{{cite web|first=Eugene|last=Kim|title=Revolutionary Tunisian Street Art|url=http://www.mymodernmet.com/profiles/blogs/revolutionary-tunisian-street|publisher=My Modern Met|accessdate=19 April 2013}}</ref>
===Abroad===
Tunisian artists also explored political and revolutionary themes in exhibits abroad. In France, the [[Institut du Monde Arabe]] hosted two events. In May 2011, an exhibit called "Dégage" (French for "get lost") showcased photographs of the revolution by a Tunisian photography collective of the same name.<ref>{{cite web|title="DÉGAGE", COLLECTIF DE PHOTOGRAPHES TUNISIENS|url=http://www.imarabe.org/exposition-ima-degage#|publisher=Institut du Monde Arabe|accessdate=18 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Farhat|first=Mehdi|title=Le collectif Dégage révèle sa révolution|url=http://www.slateafrique.com/2203/collectif-degage-revele-revolution|accessdate=18 April 2013|newspaper=Slate Afrique|date=23 May 2011}}</ref> A second exhibit that ran from January to April 2012 called "Dégagements – Tunisia One Year On" showed work from Tunisian artists and others from the Middle East to celebrate the anniversary of the revolution.<ref>{{cite web|title=DÉGAGEMENTS... LA TUNISIE UN AN APRÈS|url=http://www.imarabe.org/exposition/degagements-la-tunisie-un-apres|publisher=Institut du Monde Arabe|accessdate=18 April 2013}}</ref> It included paintings, graffiti, pictures and sculptures by artists like cartoonist Nadia Kiari and photographer [[Hichem Driss]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Charlton|first=Emma|title=Art dissects Tunisia's revolution, one year on|url=http://www.yourmiddleeast.com/features/art-dissects-tunisias-revolution-one-year-on_5086|accessdate=18 April 2013|newspaper=AFP|date=28 February 2012}}</ref>
In the United States, Tunisian student Ikram Lakhdhar curated an exhibit at Connecticut College called "Moments of Freedom: Revolutionary Art from China, South Africa and Tunisia" in April 2013 with work by contemporary Tunisian photographers Wassim Grimen, Omar Sfayhi, and Youssef Ben Ammar and internationally renown artists such as [[Diane Victor]], [[Zhang Hongtu]], [[Rajaa Gharbi]] and [[William Kentridge]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Smadhi|first=Asma|title=Tunisian Student Organizes Revolutionary Art Exhibit in US|url=http://www.tunisia-live.net/2013/04/02/tunisian-student-organizes-revolutionary-art-exhibit-in-us/|accessdate=18 April 2013|newspaper=Tunisia Live|date=2 April 2013}}</ref>
In [[Germany]], the ifa Gallery in [[Stuttgart]] hosted an exhibit from January to March 2013 called "Rosy Future" on the future of contemporary art in Tunisia after the revolution.<ref>{{cite web|title=ROSY FUTURE – CONTEMPORARY ART FROM TUNISIA |url=http://www.contemporaryand.com/blog/exhibition/rosy-future-contemporary-art-from-tunisia/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130628223624/http://www.contemporaryand.com/blog/exhibition/rosy-future-contemporary-art-from-tunisia/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=28 June 2013 |publisher=Contemporary & |accessdate=19 April 2013 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Arab Spring]] * [[Tunisian revolution]] * [[Culture of Tunisia]]

[[File:Ashanti English Medieval Ewer.jpg|thumb|Asante Ewer, British Museum, 62.3 cm high (including lid)]]
The '''Asante Ewer''' or '''Asante Jug''' is a leaded [[bronze]] lidded jug dated to the 1390s. It is a rare surviving example of an English bronze jug from the 14th century, with great significance for the study of bronze working in medieval England. It was taken from [[Kumasi]] in [[Ashanti Empire|Asante]] (now [[Ghana]]) during the [[Fourth Anglo-Ashanti War]] in 1895, and since 1896 has been held by the [[British Museum]] in London.
The front of the Asante Jug is decorated with the [[Royal Arms of England]] from the late 14th century, surmounted by a crown, with two lion [[supporters]]. Above three lines of lettering in a [[Lombardic capitals|Lombardic script]], within a moulded band, read from the bottom: : "+ HE THAT WYL NOT SPARE WHEN HE MAY HE SHALL NOT / SPEND WHEN HE WOULD DEME THE BEST IN EVERY / DOWT TIL THE TROWTHE BE TRYID OWTE" The inscription appears to be two English sentences, run together: : "He that will not spare when he may he shall not spend when he would" and "Deem the best in every doubt until the truth be tried out".
The neck of the Asante Jug bears six [[roundel]]s, three on either side, each with a falcon spreading its wings, with one to each side of the spout and two either side of the handle. On the lip are three lions facing left, and a stag in a circle facing right. The seven-sided lid of the jug is original, decorated with a lion above a stag [[couchant]] in each segment. The handle ends with a scrolled [[quatrefoil]].
Without the lid, the jug is {{convert|43.3|cm}} high, and the lid (including the overlapping underlip) is {{convert|19.6|cm}}. When assembled with its lid, the jug is {{convert|62.3|cm}} high. It weighs {{convert|18.6|kg}}, and has a capacity of {{convert|15.8|l}}. When filled, it would be inconveniently heavy to use.
Only two similar jugs are known in the UK. All have similar shapes, bear inscriptions in English with similar lettering, and were made from leaded bronze, an alloy of copper, tin and lead, cast in a two-part mould in a similar manner using bronze spacers to separate the inner and outer moulds, with similar heraldic decorative motifs. The Asante jug is the largest, and the only one to retain its lid.
Of the other two jugs, the smallest is [[Wenlok jug]] in Luton: it was sold by [[Alexander Fermor-Hesketh, 3rd Baron Hesketh]] in 2005. The third is the [[Robinson jug]], which was found in a farmhouse in Norfolk in the 1879 and is now in the collection of the [[Victoria & Albert Museum]]. The other two have fittings for a hinged lid but the lid has not survived.
All three jugs were made in England. The heraldic emblems on this jug link it to either [[Edward III]] or [[Richard II]]. The stag badges on the lid suggest Richard II, who used the white stag in the 1390s. The jug was found in [[Manhyia Palace]] in Kumasi in 1895, but when and how it arrived in West Africa is not known. It is speculated that it was carried from Europe to Africa in the Early Modern period as an impressive gift to present to an African ruler, having been bought cheaply there. There is a photograph taken in 1887 which shows the jug under a sacred tree at the royal palace.
The jug was bought by the British Museum in 1896 from Major General [[Charles St Leger Barter]], who served in the [[Fourth Anglo-Ashanti War]] in December 1895 to February 1896 (also known as the Second Ashanti Expedition) which reached [[Kumasi]] and depose the [[Asantehene]] [[Prempeh I]].
Another plainer 14th century English lidded jug is in [[Leeds City Museum]].
==References== * [http://britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=43862&partId=1 The Asante Jug], British Museum * [https://artsandculture.google.com/asset/asante-ewer/_QHI3PLK-VpmBw Asante Ewer], Google Arts & Culture * [https://www.history.ac.uk/richardII/asante.html Asante ewer], Institute of Historical Research and Royal Holloway University of London, 2007 * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/ahistoryoftheworld/objects/zaVgLWXiTXuj6LwSW5nTpQ English bronzer ewer], BBC, A History of the World * [https://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/news/leeds-s-world-changing-treasures-1-2238393 Leeds's world changing treasures], Yorkshire Evening Post, 1 February 2010 * [http://friendsoflutonmuseums.org/page19.html The Wenlok Jug], Friends of Luton Museums * [http://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O97902/robinson-jug-jug-unknown/ Robinson Jug], Victoria and Albert Museum

[[Paul Pavlovich]] }} '''Assück''' was an American [[grindcore]] band from Saint Petersburg [[Florida]], active from 1987 to 1998. The band proved influential, with their album ''Anticapital'' (1991) voted number 4 in the ''[[Terrorizer (magazine)|Terrorizer]]'' list of their top 20 US grindcore albums, who described it as a "low-calibre battery of brooding, malicious, doom-ridden grind pitched somewhere between early [[Napalm Death]] and even earlier [[Bolt Thrower]]".Hoare, James (March 2009). "Criminal Records: Essential Records|US", ''[[Terrorizer (magazine)|Terrorizer]]'' 181, p. 44. According to journalist Greg Pratt, "Assück were an incredible band with probably metal's best drummer [Rob Proctor], although no one ever mentions his name. They combined well-written poetic and political lyrics with catchy songs, insane musicianship and a short-fast-loud brutality that no one has topped since."Stewart-Panko, Kevin (March 2009). "US Grind", ''Terrorizer'' 181, p. 43. Writing for ''[[Maximumrocknroll]]'', Felix von Havoc describes the political punk and metal roots of this band, stating "Assuck managed to combine the anger, fury and social commentary of a punk band {{About|a form of Azerbaijani folk poetry|other uses|Bayat (disambiguation)}}
'''Bayati''' ({{lang-az|Bayatı}}) is one of the oldest forms of [[Azerbaijani people|Azerbaijani]] folk poetry. A bayati consists of four lines, each of which has seven syllables. The rhyme scheme is aaba. Anonymous bayati have been collected as folk wisdom in editions such as ''Xalqimizin deyimlari va duyumlari'' (Our people's sayings and feelings). Bayati can also be strung together in sequence to form longer poems, and there are several bayati dastan, epics, in which all of the verses are bayati; one example is ''Arzu-Qamber''.<ref name="Oldfield"/>
Some folklorists associate the bayati with women's folk creativity, but male [[ashig]]s compose bayati as well. Intriguingly, some scholars argue that the bayati dastan are from a lost repertoire of women's dastan, but so far there is no firm evidence to support this theory. In the [[Zaqatala Rayon|Zagatala]] region of northern [[Azerbaijan]], male and female ashiqs who play the [[tanbur]] sing poetry composed only in the bayati meter.<ref name="Oldfield">Anna C. Oldfield. Azerbaijani Women Poet-minstrels: Women Ashiqs from the Eighteenth Century to the Present. Edwin Mellen Press, 2008. P. 60.</ref>

The '''calygreyhound''' is a mythical creature, that appears on [[Medieval]] [[heraldry]]. The de Vere family, who were the [[Earls of Oxford]], used the calygreyhound in their coat of arms in the 15th and 16th centuries.<ref>{{Cite journal | date =2003-04-01 | title =Fabulous Beasts in Tudor Heraldry | periodical =Dragonlore | publisher =The Journal of The College of Dracology | issue =31 | pages =4 | url =http://www.dragonlore.co.uk/magazines/issue31.pdf | accessdate =2008-10-08}}</ref> The calygreyhound may be unique to the de Veres,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pvv.ntnu.no/~bcd/rolemaster/novi/her-list.txt |title=ENCYCLOPEDIA OF NOVI: HERALDRY |first=Lowell R. |last=Matthews |accessdate=2008-10-08}}</ref> and unlike most heraldic monsters, it made no attempt to seem realistic. A similar monster is the [[caretyne]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.americancollegeofheraldry.org/TANAPR04.htm |title=Proportions |first=Anthony |last=Wood |work=The Armiger's News |date=April 2004 |accessdate=2008-10-08}}</ref>
==Description== The calygreyhound is described consistently as having the head of a [[wildcat]],<ref name=oxfordjournal>{{Cite journal | date =July 1955 | title =Memorabilia | periodical =Notes and Queries | publisher =[[Oxford University Press]] | url =http://nq.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/issue_pdf/frontmatter_pdf/CC/jul.pdf | accessdate =2008-10-08}}</ref> the torso of a [[deer]] or [[antelope]],<ref name=ue>{{cite web |url=http://www.unknownexplorers.com/calygreyhound.php |title=Unknown Explorers - Calygreyhound |publisher=Unknownexplorers.com |accessdate=2008-10-08}}</ref> the claws of an [[eagle]] on its forefeet, [[ox]] hooves, antlers or horns, the hind legs of a lion or ox, and its tail like a lion or [[poodle]]. On some rare occasions, the Calygreyhound may be seen as depicted with the wings of an eagle.<ref name=oxfordjournal /> It is said to represent speed or swiftness.<ref name=ue /> It is generally accepted that the calygreyhound is simply a figment of the artist's imagination, but some parts of it are based on reality. When it is depicted, it does not have a consistent position.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://heralds.westkingdom.org/Templates/Beasts/ |title=SCA - West Kingdom College of Heralds - Heraldic Templates |publisher=West Kingdom College |accessdate=2008-10-08}}</ref>
